DOC.HEAD: Cuba's Plans to Foul U.S. TV Transmission Pass First Tests
DOC.TEXT: Cuba has performed successful initial tests on equipment to jam planned TV broadcasts to Cuba by the U.S. government, the island's official news service said Tuesday. Granma, the official daily newspaper of the Communist government, said the effectiveness of the interference devices ``has been partly proven.'' The United States has been broadcasting radio transmissions to Cuba via Radio Marti for five years. Congress backed funds for television broadcasts earlier this year. In a joint statement published in Granma, Cuba's Communications Ministry, armed forces and Radio and Television Institute said the Cuban plan was prompted by the U.S. government's intention to put into operation an anti-Cuban ``Television Marti'' next month, Prensa Latina said. ``Faced with the Yankee threat to begin transmissions against Cuba, larger-scale tests will be realized on national television transmissions,'' the joint statement said. It said Cuban equipment would achieve ``a considerable level of degradation of the enemy signal.'' The U.S. transmissions constitute ``a flagrant violation of national sovereignty and the norms and regulations for telecommunications established by the United Nations and other international organizations,'' the Cuban government statement said.
